Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old man with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and urosepsis. He was admitted to the ICU and received invasive ventilation but was extubated yesterday. The patient still requires a significant amount of oxygen and is being treated empirically for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 35.6°C (96.1°F), heart rate of 95 bpm, blood pressure of 140/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on nasal cannula with FiO2 of 50%. His physical examination shows no acute distress, thin appearance, and right lower extremity edema. The patient's laboratory results indicate anemia, elevated white blood cell count, slightly low sodium levels, and normal kidney function. The patient's medical complications include respiratory failure, VAP, urosepsis, altered mental status, hyperglycemia, electrolyte and fluid disorder, and urinary tract infection. The patient is currently on DVT prophylaxis, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and antibiotic therapy for VAP and urosepsis. The patient's code status is DNR, and he will remain in the ICU for further care.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 84-year-old gentleman who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, hematuria, and elevated lactate. He required pressor support upon admission and was found to have OSH Cx positive for GPCs and strep viridans in urine. The patient was started on ampicillin but developed a fever and was then broadened to Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro due to spiking fevers and hypotension. The patient has been extubated and tolerating well, but still requires suctioning of secretions. He has severe emphysema on CT scan and is at risk for developing left-sided infiltrate.

The patient is now off of pressors and is improving, but will continue with a 14-day course of antibiotics. His altered mental status is likely multifactorial due to infection and toxic/metabolic from medications. He is being kept off of sedation. A CTA of the head and neck did not reveal abnormalities.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and has been paced for unclear underlying rhythm. His current rhythm is paced and tachycardic. He was on home digoxin, but his digoxin level here was normal. 

The patient has mild right upper extremity edema without pain, which will be ruled out for possible thrombus. He also has neck soreness, which appears to be musculoskeletal due to position, extub

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, hematuria, and elevated lactate. The patient has a history of multiple medical conditions including coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and altered mental status. He is currently on broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected sepsis secondary to a urinary tract infection (UTI) with Enterococcus and Streptococcus viridans in his urine.

The patient's current status shows improvement in several areas. His respiratory status has stabilized after being extubated, although he still requires suctioning of secretions. His blood pressure is within normal limits, and his heart rate is controlled. Oxygen saturation is maintained at 96% with the use of a nasal cannula.

Laboratory results indicate some abnormalities, including elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. His blood glucose levels have normalized after being in the 500s upon admission. Renal function has improved with a decreasing creatinine level. Electrolyte imbalances are present, including low potassium and magnesium levels.

Imaging studies reveal bilateral infiltrates and pleural effusions on chest X-ray, consistent with his history of severe emphysema. A CT scan of the head and neck did not reveal any abnormalities.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics for a total of 14 days, titrating oxygen to maintain saturation

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with sepsis secondary to a urinary tract infection and respiratory failure. He has been extubated and is showing improvement. The patient has a history of failed swallow study, indicating the need for a Dobhoff tube for nutrition. He has no known drug allergies. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 100 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 139/74 mmHg to 156/113 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on nasal cannula. He is receiving multiple medications including morphine sulfate, as well as antibiotics for his UTI. The patient's blood products and fluid balance show positive intake and output over the past 24 hours. He is receiving respiratory support with an O2 delivery device and his ABG results are pending. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds, trace lower extremity edema, warm skin, and attentive neurologic status. Lab results indicate leukocytosis, anemia, thrombocytosis, hyponatremia, hyperglycemia, and altered liver function tests. The patient's medical complications include respiratory failure, sepsis with organ dysfunction, hyperglycemia, electrolyte/fluid disorder, urinary tract infection, altered mental status, and acute renal failure. The plan includes stopping vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin since cultures have been negative. The patient should complete 14 days of ampicillin for septic shock/UTI. Other management plans include improving MS, anticoagulation for AFib, and resolution of acute renal failure. Foley catheter should be continued, and a Dobhoff tube will be needed. The central line will be pulled and a PIC line will be placed. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition support, glycemic control, line management, prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcers, and VAP. The patient's code status is full code, and he is currently in the ICU.

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old gentleman who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, hematuria, and elevated lactate. He required a pressor upon admission and was found to have OSH Cx positive for GPC and strep viridans in urine. He was started on ampicillin but developed higher temperatures, leading to the broadening of antibiotics to Vanc/Cefipime/Cipro. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, for which he had a pacemaker placed. He is currently paced and tachycardic.

The patient's current assessment includes:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has done well post-extubation but still requires suctioning of secretions. He has severe emphysema on CT scan and is experiencing respiratory failure with tachypnea and a possible left-sided infiltrate.

2. Sepsis: The patient appears to have had urosepsis with positive UCx, although all blood cultures have been negative. He has had multiple previous UTIs, and there was a traumatic foley placement at OSH. He was initially on just ampicillin but was broadened to Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro due to spiking fevers and hypotension. He is now off pressors and improved but will continue with a 14-day course of antibiotics. If he continues to improve, consideration may be given to returning to just ampicillin after 48 hours of negative

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 84-year-old gentleman with a history of respiratory failure, hematuria, and elevated lactate. He was admitted to the ICU with sepsis and severe emphysema. The patient required extubation and is currently on a face tent with high-flow oxygen. He also has a positive UCx for GPC and strep viridans in his urine. His blood cultures have been negative. The patient was started on ampicillin but developed fevers, so the antibiotics were broadened to Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro. The patient is now off pressors and improving, but will continue with a 14-day course of antibiotics.

The patient has several medical complications including respiratory failure, sepsis, acute pain, chronic pain, diarrhea, cardiac dysrhythmia, altered nutrition, electrolyte & fluid disorder, urinary tract infection (UTI), and altered mental status. He also has a history of coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus.

Plan:
1. Continue Albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers.
2. Titrate O2 to sat in low 90s.
3. Discuss with daughter whether re-intubation is an option if he does poorly again after extubation.
4. Check afternoon ABG.
5. Discontinue vancomycin and cefepime if afebrile and no growth on micro.
6. Continue

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old man with severe COPD and respiratory failure. He requires frequent suctioning due to poor secretion clearance. The patient has been desaturating, indicating potential oxygenation issues. He has a history of allergies to specific antibiotics. The patient is currently on multiple medications including heparin sodium for prophylaxis, atrovent/albuterol, famotidine, digoxin, and morphine. His vital signs are within normal limits, but he is on mechanical ventilation support. The patient has a history of cardiac dysrhythmia, alteration in nutrition, sepsis, respiratory failure, hyperglycemia, electrolyte & fluid disorder, urinary tract infection, and altered mental status. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory distress due to poor secretion clearance and potential inadequate oxygenation.
2. Metabolic alkalosis from prior lasix use.
3. Cardiac dysrhythmia, possibly atrial fibrillation.
4. Sepsis with organ dysfunction.
5. Hyperglycemia.
6. Electrolyte & fluid disorder.
7. Urinary tract infection.
8. Altered mental status.
9. Potential complications related to the use of mechanical ventilation support.
10. Possible deep vein thrombosis due to immobilization.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old man with severe COPD and respiratory failure. He requires frequent suctioning overnight and is desaturating this morning. The patient has several medical conditions and complications, including acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), sepsis with organ dysfunction, hyperglycemia, electrolyte and fluid disorder, urinary tract infection (UTI), altered mental status (not delirium), and acute cardiac dysrhythmia.

The patient's vital signs show a heart rate of 94 bpm, blood pressure of 119/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. His temperature is within normal range at 36.6°C (97.8°F). The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently on digoxin.

Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelet count. Blood glucose levels are fluctuating, with readings ranging from 79 to 113 mg/dL. Electrolyte levels show abnormalities in sodium, potassium, chloride, and magnesium. The patient also has elevated blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, and lactate levels.

The patient's chest X-ray is not available for assessment. He has trace edema in both lower extremities and soft, non-tender abdomen with present bowel sounds.

The patient's current plan includes pain control, managing acute and chronic pain

   An 84 year old gentleman admitted from [**Hospital3 33**] Hospital with
   respiratory failure, hematuria and elevated lactate, who developed a
   pressor requirement upon admission, had OSH Cx
s positive for GPC
s and
   was started on Ampicillin but spiked higher temps and now broadened to
   Vanc/Cefipime/Cipro, with enterococcus and strep viridans in urine.
   Extubated yesterday, tolerating well, secretions needing to be
   suctioned.
   #Respiratory Failure:  He has done well following extubation on a face
   tent with high flow oxygen, though still requiring suctioning of
   secretions.  Patient with severe emphysema on CT scan with respiratory
   failure in the setting of acidosis with tachypnea and possible
   developing left sided infiltrate.
   - CXR daily
   - titrate O2 to PO2 in low 90s.
   - Continue Albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers.
   #Sepsis:  On presentation appears to have had urosepsis, w/ positive
   UCx though all blood has been negative.  Has had multiple previous
   UTI
s, and then with traumatic foley placement at OSH.  He was on just
   Ampicillin but was then broadened to Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro, day 2 due to
   spiking fevers and hypotension [**12-23**].  He is now off of pressors and
   improved, but we will continue for a 14-day course of antibiotics.
   Though if he continues to improve, may consider returning to just
   ampicillin after 48 hours of negative cultures.   Discontinued
   vancomycin and cefepime (had been started for spike and concern for
   VAP, but now afebrile and no growth on micro).  Currently on Ampicillin
   - Continue Ampicillin, today is day #[**1-9**] (initiated [**12-18**] for
   complicated UTI)
   - Currently afebrile.  Watch fever curve, consider cx and broadening
   abxif spikes  --> restart vanc/cefepime, and/or add flagyl
   - IVF for UOP < 30 cc/hr, SBP < 90
   #Altered mental status: Patient is improving and is now interactive and
   following commands.  His altered mental status is likely multifactorial
   due to infection and toxic/metabolic from medications.  He is being
   kept off of sedation.  CTA of head and neck did not reveal
   abnormalities.
   - improved, monitor clinically
   #Atrial fibrillation/PVCs:  Patient s/p pacemaker for unclear
   underlying rhythm although [**Hospital3 33**] notes history of atrial
   fibrillation. He has been between sinus tachycardia with PVC
   intermittent conduction block, and his current rhythm is paced and
   tachycardic. He was on home Digoxin which we had not restarted due to a
   normal rate in the past, but is intermittently tachy to the low 100
   Digoxin level here was normal.
   - contact PCP to discuss possible anticoagulation
   - Digoxin converted from home PO to IV regimen.
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Right Upper Extremity Edema:  Mild right upper extremity edema
   without pain
 will rule out possible thrombus
 ultrasound negative
   for clot. Edema less asymmetric today
 resolving.
   - monitor clinically
   # Neck soreness
 appears MSK due to position, extubation, etc.
 warm compress, plan to remove CVL after PICC placed, morphine liquid
   elixir drops on tongue (failed speech & swallow), change position
   Other less acute or stable issues:
   #Acute Renal Failure:  Creatinine now in normal range. On admission,
   was likely pre-renal in the setting of sepsis, may also have component
   of ATN and initially post-renal obstruction.  Foley catheter now
   successfully placed. Cr has been trending down nicely with IVF's and

Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old gentleman admitted with respiratory failure, hematuria, and elevated lactate. He had a positive OSH Cx for GPCs and was started on ampicillin but developed a fever and broadened to Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro due to suspected enterococcus and strep viridans in urine. The patient is now extubated, tolerating well, and requires suctioning of secretions. He has severe emphysema on CT scan with respiratory failure in the setting of acidosis and tachypnea. There is a possible developing left-sided infiltrate, and the CXR looks improved but with some pulmonary edema. The patient has been on a 14-day course of antibiotics and may consider returning to just ampicillin after 48 hours of negative cultures. He is currently afebrile and off of pressors.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has severe emphysema and is still requiring supplemental oxygen. There is a possibility of developing left-sided infiltrate, indicating potential pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: Although the patient is currently improving, there is a risk of recurrent sepsis due to his history of multiple UTIs and positive UCx. Monitoring for any signs of fever or hypotension is essential.
3. Cardiac Dysrhythmia: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently paced due to intermittent

The patient is an 84-year-old male with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and chronic kidney disease. He was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and hematuria. The patient has been treated for sepsis, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection, urinary tract infection (UTI), acute kidney injury, and other comorbidities.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of severe emphysema and is currently experiencing respiratory failure. Continuous monitoring of oxygen saturation levels and daily chest X-rays will be necessary to assess the progression of the condition.

2. Sepsis: The patient presented with urosepsis, which is a severe systemic infection that can lead to organ dysfunction. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been initiated, and the patient's response to treatment will be closely monitored.

3. UTI: The patient has a history of multiple UTIs, and the current infection is caused by enterococcus and streptococcus viridans. Antibiotic therapy will be continued for a 14-day course, with consideration of returning to ampicillin if the patient continues to improve and has negative cultures.

4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient initially had acute renal failure, but his creatinine levels have returned to baseline. Close monitoring of renal function and fluid balance is crucial to

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of respiratory failure, which is currently being managed with diuretics to remove excess fluid. Close monitoring of respiratory function and oxygenation is necessary to prevent further deterioration.

2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to the UTI. Continued administration of appropriate antibiotics and careful monitoring of vital signs and organ dysfunction are crucial to managing this condition.

   An 84 year old gentleman admitted from [**Hospital3 33**] Hospital with
   respiratory failure, hematuria and elevated lactate, who developed a
   pressor requirement upon admission, had OSH Cx
s positive for GPC
s and
   was started on Ampicillin but spiked higher temps and now broadened to
   Vanc/Cefipime/Cipro, with enterococcus and strep viridans in urine. On
   pressors previously, now weaned off.  Now extubated, tolerating well.
   #Respiratory Failure:  He has done well following extubation on a face
   tent with high flow oxygen, though still requiring suctioning of
   secretions.  Patient with severe emphysema on CT scan with respiratory
   failure in the setting of acidosis with tachypnea and possible
   developing left sided infiltrate.  CXR looks improved but with some
   pulmonary edema.
   - Weaning O2 down; now on humidified mask at 6L.  Continue titrating
   down O2 as tolerated to PO2 in low 90s.
   - Lasix prn for SOB, not giving any today
   - Continue Albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers.
   #Sepsis:  On presentation appears to have had urosepsis, w/ positive
   UCx though all blood has been negative.  Has had multiple previous
   UTI
s, and then with traumatic foley placement at OSH.  He was on just
   Ampicillin but was then broadened to Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro, day 2 due to
   spiking fevers and hypotension [**12-23**].  He is now off of pressors and
   improved, but we will continue for a 14-day course of antibiotics.
   Though if he continues to improve, may consider returning to just
   ampicillin after 48 hours of negative cultures.   Discontinued
   vancomycin and cefepime (had been started for spike and concern for
   VAP, but now afebrile and no growth on micro).  Currently on
   Ampicillin.
   - Continue Ampicillin, today is day #13/14 (initiated [**12-18**] for
   complicated UTI)
   - Currently afebrile.  Watch fever curve, consider cx and broadening
   abxif spikes  --> restart vanc/cefepime, and/or add flagyl
   #Atrial fibrillation/PVCs:  Patient s/p pacemaker for unclear
   underlying rhythm although [**Hospital3 33**] notes history of atrial
   fibrillation. He has been between sinus tachycardia with PVC
   intermittent conduction block, and his current rhythm is paced and
   tachycardic. He was on home Digoxin which we had not restarted due to a
   normal rate in the past, but is intermittently tachy to the low 100
   Digoxin level here was normal.
   - Digoxin (PO home med)
   - ASA 325mg as anticoagulation, as not on coumadin given fall risk
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Neck soreness
 appears MSK due to position, extubation, etc.
 warm compress, morphine liquid elixir drops on tongue (failed speech
   & swallow), change position
   - Tylenol standing
   # Leukocytosis
 unclear etiology, consider c.diff given multiple
   antibiotics recently
   - check c.diff if stools before discharge, but not currently having
   diarrhea
   - if develops diarrhea at rehab, consider c.diff testing and treatment
   Other less acute or stable issues:
   #Altered mental status: Patient is improving and is now interactive and
   following commands.  His altered mental status is likely multifactorial
   due to infection and toxic/metabolic from medications.  He is being
   kept off of sedation.  CTA of head and neck did not reveal
   abnormalities.
   - improved, monitor clinically
   # Right Upper Extremity Edema:  Ultrasound negative for clot. Resolved.
   #Acute Renal Failure:  Creatinine now in normal range. On admission,
   was likely pre-renal in the setting of sepsis, may also have component
   of ATN and initially post-renal obstruction.  Foley catheter now
   successfully placed. Cr has been trending down nicely with IVF's and
   currently at baseline.
   - Trend Cr and UOP with IVF to maintain UOP > 30 cc/hr if possible
   - Foley catheter now in place = do NOT take out, per Urology, as below
   - Write in d/c summary importance of contacting urology and NOT taking
   out foley
   # Metabolic Alkalosis: Resolved. Bicarb slightly improved.  After
   extubation, he should be able to adjust his own acid-base status.  Most
   likely he is chronically hypoventilating and slightly acidotic, causing
   him to raise his bicarb.  Follow ABG
s if dictated by respiratory
   status.
   #Traumatic Foley Placement:  Patient transferred after concern that
   foley may be placed in scrotum.  Initial CT concerning for
   intraabdominal placement, now most likely instead bladder
   diverticulum.  Urology did cystoscopy and placed Foley. Their recs are
   to keep Foley in place, do not remove without asking urology first,
   keep secure to thigh with 2 catheter secures, f/u with Urology when
   acute illness over.
   #Elevated Blood Sugars:  Resolved. Blood sugars in the 500s on arrival
   to the MICU and started on insulin gtt. Gtt has now been stopped and
   his BS's have been appropriately in the 100's.
   #Coronary Artery Disease:  Details unclear.
   - change aspirin 81mg daily (home med) to 325mg daily given afib
   #Hyperlipidemia:
   - continue lipitor 10mg daily (home med)
   FEN: no IVF today, replete electrolytes prn, tubefeeds by Dobhoff
   Nutren pulmonary, oral nystatin. NPO. Bowel regimen.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PO lansoprazole.
   Access: PICC line. Pull peripheral IV and arterial line today before
   discharge.
   Code:  DNR, DNI. Per daughter, NO chest compressions, nothing to make
   him suffer. DNR, DNI.
   Communication: Patient, Wife [**Name (NI) 10077**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10078**], Son [**Name (NI) 5371**], Daughter
   [**Name (NI) 412**] is very involved
   Disposition: Rehab today.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 84-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, hematuria, and elevated lactate. He has a history of atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease. The patient was started on ampicillin but developed a fever and his condition worsened, leading to the broadening of antibiotics to vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin due to positive cultures for enterococcus and streptococcus viridans in the urine. The patient is currently extubated and tolerating well on a face tent with high flow oxygen. 

The potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has severe emphysema and is at risk for developing left-sided infiltrates. There is improvement in the chest X-ray, but pulmonary edema is still present. The plan is to wean down the oxygen and continue with nebulizers.
2. Sepsis: The patient initially presented with urosepsis, and despite being off pressors, he is still on a 14-day course of antibiotics. If he continues to improve, there may be a consideration of returning to just ampicillin after 48 hours of negative cultures.
3. Atrial fibrillation/PVCs: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently paced and tachycardic. Digoxin has been restarted,

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 84-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, hematuria, and elevated lactate. He required pressor support upon admission and was found to have an obstructive shock cardiac cause positive for GPCs and strep viridans in his urine. The patient was started on ampicillin but developed a fever and the antibiotic regimen was broadened to vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin due to suspected enterococcus and strep viridans infection. He has since improved and is now extubated, tolerating well on a face tent with high flow oxygen.

The patient has a history of severe emphysema and developed left-sided infiltrate with pulmonary edema. He is being weaned off oxygen and receiving Lasix for fluid management. The patient also has a history of atrial fibrillation, for which he had a pacemaker placement. He is currently paced and tachycardic, and Digoxin has been restarted.

Other issues include neck soreness, which is likely musculoskeletal due to position and extubation. The patient is also experiencing altered mental status, likely multifactorial due to infection and medication toxicity. His mental status has improved with interaction and following commands. A CT angiography of the head and neck did not reveal any abnormalities.

The patient had right upper extremity edema, which resolved with an ultrasound negative for clot. He also had acute

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 84-year-old male with severe COPD and respiratory failure. He is currently in the ICU and is being treated for various conditions. The patient has no known drug allergies. His current vital signs include a temperature of 36.2 C, heart rate of 66 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 130/54 mmHg to 163/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 91%. The patient is experiencing atrial fibrillation.

The patient has been receiving several medications including furosemide, heparin sodium, lipitor, digoxin, and morphine as needed. He also had a PICC line inserted on 12/29/2129 at 12:45 PM and was later removed on the same day at 6:33 PM.

The patient's lab results show elevated levels of white blood cells, hemoglobin, platelets, creatinine, total bilirubin, glucose, and lactate. His electrolyte levels are within normal range, except for slightly low potassium and magnesium levels. Other lab values are also provided.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Pain control - acute and chronic pain management.
2. Diarrhea.
3. Cardiac dysrhythmia (other).
4. Alteration in nutrition.
5. Sepsis, severe (with organ dysfunction).
6. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS).
7. Hyperglycemia.
8. Electrolyte & fluid disorder, other.
9. Urinary tract infection (UTI).
10. Altered mental status (not delirium).

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the information provided, the patient is at risk for several medical complications including respiratory failure, sepsis, UTI, hyperglycemia, electrolyte imbalances, and potential cardiac issues due to atrial fibrillation. Close monitoring and appropriate management of these conditions are crucial for the patient's well-being.
